awd_titl_txt: Robert Noyce Program in Mathematics at the University of Houston-Clear Lake
awd_abstract_narration: The University of Houston at Clear Lake, whose student body is entirely juniors and seniors, has a Noyce project to prepare 15 current and transfer students to become highly qualified secondary-school mathematics teachers.  Mathematics and Education faculty collaborate with over 55 local schools in 22 districts to prepare teachers in a program that includes a two-semester internship and opportunities for interaction with the adjoining NASA Johnson Space Center, among other local scientific agencies.  Students are trained not only in mathematics content and pedagogy, but are taught to use critical thinking, instructional technology, and strategies to address English-language learners.  The program allows potential scholars to explore mathematics teaching as a profession through the Success Through Education Programs and opportunities to conduct internships at summer camps or other mathematically oriented programs.  Once selected as Noyce Scholars, the students complete their mathematics major while enrolling in courses to learn pedagogy.  After completing their degrees and certification, alumni of the program serve as mentors for newer preservice teachers and receive continuing professional development in their induction period. Since most of the students are transfers from community colleges, they come from diverse backgrounds.  The UHCL program deliberately recruits students who are underrepresented minority, low income, or first in their families to attend college.  Since they are from local secondary schools and community colleges, and since their practice teaching will also be local, they are likely to remain in the area, "home-grown" teachers of the next generation.

por.por_cntn:
The University of Houston-Clear Lake (UHCL) Robert Noyce Program in Mathematics awarded seventeen (17) scholarships, two (2) more than initially proposed in the grant submission. These students, upon completion of all requirements for Texas teaching certification, are committed to teaching mathematics in high needs middle/ high schools. As of December 2021, eleven (11) scholars have obtained teaching positions. Three (3) students are completing their degree and teaching certifications, one stepped out and obtained a M.S. in Instructional Design and Technology, and is currently enrolled in the EdD Curriculum and instruction STEM program, while two (2) have stepped out of the program due to family financial issues.

Intellectual Merit: The Robert Noyce program capitalized on the outstanding resources and programs in the local area to provide scholarship students expertise in: 1) mathematics content, 2) pedagogy, 3) teaching critical thinking, 4) use of instructional technology and 5) working with English language learners. program provided Robert Noyce scholarships to 17 undergraduate students.

The Robert Noyce Scholarship a program at UHCL was a  comprehensive program of recruitment, training, and support for mathematics teachers. Students interacted with the program through three stages. In the First Stage, high school students, community college students and UHCL mathematics majors explored mathematics teaching as a profession; in the Second Stage, qualified UHCL students took part as Noyce Scholars, and in the Third Stage, students who have graduated became Noyce alumni and participated in professional development and support as they fulfilled their teaching commitment.

Broader Impact: Since UHCL is in a large metropolitan area and places teacher candidate interns/teachers in over 22 local school districts, there are many career opportunities for participants in the UHCL Noyce Program. Most of the local school districts are either high minority and/or high-need and are characterized by a large percentage of mathematics teachers who lack appropriate teaching certification. Therefore, given the needs of local school districts and the successful teacher preparation program at UHCL, UHCL’s Robert Noyce Program would have a large impact on local school districts in addressing the need for certified STEM teachers in. Recruitment focused on reaching minority, low-income, and first-generation college students who make up a significant percentage of the local community college and UHCL student body. A focus on mathematics addressed an identified area of need for teachers in the State of Texas.

Goals of the UHCL Robert Noyce Program in Mathematics:

1. To encourage mathematics majors to enter teaching careers.

2. To select the most qualified candidates with potential to be successful teachers.

3. To maintain at least 80% of the Noyce Program students each year and assist them in the successful attainment of their degrees and/or certifications.

4. To certify at least 15 new mathematics teachers over the Robert Noyce Program and assist them in fulfilling their teaching requirements.

5. To address needs of local school districts by placing well-qualified mathematics teachers in high need areas.

6. To put in place at UHCL a model for STEM teacher recruitment and training which will continue well beyond the grant period and be expanded to other fields (e.g., physics).

Project goals were met as evidenced by successful completion and placement of eleven (11) scholars with an additional three (3) scholars making positive academic progress. UHCL is has become a replication site for the successful UTEACH program (Math, Science, Computer Science) to serve as a model for STEM teacher preparation, recruitment, and training.

Recruitment efforts were challenging due to UHCL’s position as an upper level institution at award time; placing dependency on community college partners for recruitment. In 2014, UHCL transitioned to a four-year institution and scholarship applicants increased. Students continued to be recruited from partner community colleges. Serving non-traditional student populations (transfer, non-residential) created barriers to cohort model sustainability. Recruiting students for Mathematics certification was challenging and it is anticipated the UTEACH model will improve preparation and increase interest and recruitment efforts as well as provide cohort model support.

Challenges to successful certification testing was addressed by offering workshops delivered by current middle/high school teachers. The tutoring model has been institutionalized and is offered to all teacher candidates at UHCL. UHCL scholars had opportunities to participate in on-campus/off-campus STEM workshops. Several scholars attended Regional/National Noyce Conferences.

In addition to field experiences through teacher education coursework, scholars had opportunities to work in UHCL’s KidsU summer program across all STEM areas, offering insights into integrated curriculum. Working with KidsU camps provided immersive classroom experiences.

Scholar tracking indicates program graduates are having a positive impact on student learning outcomes high need districts. Retention has been equally positive. Outcomes of the UHCL Robert Noyce Program in Mathematics has served to inform practices such as preparation, tutoring, as well as scholar tracking and obligation. These practices will be implemented in any future NOYCE awards.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/21/2021
Modified by: Jana M Willis
